conclusion: Use Faraday's Law of Induction to find the maximum induced EMF.
The loop is an equilateral triangle with side length \(a\), moving uniformly to the right with speed \(v\), and side \(CD\) is always perpendicular to \(MN\).
The magnetic field \(B\) is uniform and perpendicular to the plane of the loop.
As the loop enters the field, the area of the loop within the magnetic field increases, changing the magnetic flux.
The side \(CD\) is perpendicular to the boundary and enters the field first.
The area of the triangular loop is \(A = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} a^2\).
The change in area \(dA\) is related to the movement of side \(CD\) into the field.
The induced EMF \(\mathcal{E}\) is given by \(\mathcal{E} = B \cdot \left(\frac{dA}{dt}\right)\).
The rate of change of area is related to the speed \(v\) and the length of the side entering the field.
The length \(DE\) is the height of the triangle, which is \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} a\).
The change in area is proportional to \(v\) and the length of the side in the field.
The maximum EMF occurs when the entire side \(CD\) is just entering the field.
The EMF is \(\mathcal{E} = B \cdot (v \cdot DE) = B \cdot v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} a\).
The maximum induced EMF is given by \(\mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = B v a\).
